content: How can I help you today?

I'm here because my wife wanted me to try this. Things at home haven’t been great—my son’s been struggling, and it’s putting a lot of stress on my marriage and family. To be honest, I’m skeptical about therapy, but I’m willing to try it for them.

That’s a lot to have on your shoulders, and it shows a lot of care for your family that you’re willing to try this, even though you’re feeling skeptical. It sounds like the stress and challenges at home have been hard to navigate. Would you like to talk more about what’s going on with your son or how all of this has been affecting you?

My son has been acting out a lot lately—he’s angry, defiant, and difficult to handle. My wife and I have no idea what to do anymore, and it’s putting a ton of tension between us. I feel like we’re failing him, and it’s taking a toll on how I feel about myself too.

It sounds like you’re feeling overwhelmed and torn, wanting the best for your son while also handling the strain it’s placing on your marriage and your own feelings about yourself. That's a lot to carry. Can you tell me how all of this has been affecting your day-to-day life?

I just feel like I can't focus on anything else—work is impossible, I can't enjoy anything anymore, and I feel like I’m constantly on edge. I don’t even know how to be present or happy around my daughter because I’m so consumed with trying to figure out how to be there for my son and save my marriage. It’s exhausting.

This sounds incredibly draining, like you’re juggling so much that you barely have space for yourself or moments of joy. Feeling consumed by worry and responsibilities must make it hard to feel balanced or even hopeful. How do you feel about taking small steps to support yourself in all of this?

Honestly, I don’t even know where to start. I’ve been so consumed with everyone else’s needs that I haven’t thought about what support for myself would even look like. It feels selfish, and I don’t know if I even have the energy for that right now.

It’s understandable that focusing on yourself might feel selfish, especially when you’re so dedicated to your family. At the same time, it sounds like you're running on empty, and taking care of yourself might help you be there for them in a more sustainable way. What do you think about exploring small things that help you recharge or find a moment of peace?

I don’t really know. I’m just so used to pushing through everything and trying to fix the problem that I don’t think much about myself. It feels like there’s no time for that anyway, but I guess I could maybe try if it helps long-term.

It’s a big shift to think about caring for yourself when you’ve been focused on fixing everything else, but even small moments for yourself can make a difference long-term. What’s one thing you used to enjoy or find comforting before things got this overwhelming?

I used to love going for runs or listening to music, but now even those things feel like a chore. I miss the way they used to clear my head, though. Maybe I could try starting with one of those again.

That’s a great insight—you remember how running or listening to music helped you feel clearer and more at ease in the past. Starting with just a little, like one run or taking a few minutes to listen to music, could reconnect you with those feelings. How do you feel about setting aside a small, manageable time for one of those activities?
I guess I could try carving out a little bit of time for myself, even if it’s just a quick run or listening to a song I like. It feels strange to focus on me, but it might help clear my head a bit.

That’s a thoughtful step forward—it’s not easy focusing on yourself when you’re used to prioritizing others, but even a small effort can help you feel a little relief. Is it okay if this conversation shifts toward planning how you might make this small step work for you? Or is there more you’d like to explore first?
I think I could try talking through how to make this work. It’s all a bit overwhelming, so having a plan might help me actually stick to it.

That sounds like a good way forward—having some structure could make this feel more manageable. So far, you’ve mentioned running and listening to music as things that used to help you clear your head. Let’s take a moment to reflect: what small, realistic steps could fit into your current routine to help you reconnect with one of those activities without it feeling overwhelming?

Maybe I could start with just a short run, even if it’s just 10 or 15 minutes after work or first thing in the morning. Or I could make an effort to listen to a couple of my favorite songs while I’m driving or doing something else. Starting small feels more doable.

Those are excellent ideas—short runs or listening to music during everyday moments sound like practical, low-pressure ways to get started. It respects the overwhelming feelings you're managing while still creating space for yourself. What could help you commit to this, even when things feel heavy or chaotic?

Maybe setting a reminder on my phone or even asking my wife to encourage me could help. I think just starting small and reminding myself it’s okay to take that time would make it feel less overwhelming.

Those sound like thoughtful ways to keep yourself on track—reminders and support from your wife could really help you focus on this without adding too much pressure. You’re making a great effort to find manageable steps. Would you like to talk more about staying motivated, or do you feel ready to give this a try?
